Posts.Content: I did see it...very funny, I can see myself posting something at 2am :-)  Couch in March, trying not to think how different I will be feeling by then...ugh...so glad there is so much supportxx
Posts.Title: Not Sleeping

Posts.Content: Had herbal tea - it was lovely, but still wide awake.  It's such a long journey two operations and Chemo, I shall keep everything crossed for you that the 2nd round will not be too bad.  It's not easy with young children, but it must be difficult for you as well, mothers always want to protect and shield their children whatever the age, they do keep us soldiering on!!  I am having my second round of results on Wednesday, and my pre-op on Thursday - so not looking forward...
Posts.Title: Not Sleeping

Posts.Content: Thank you for being such a Gparkle(s), this really helps.  I will try the breathing exercises, I did eventually fall asleep on the couch last night and woke up to a zombie movie!  I am going to try a herbal tea which I've bought in a health food store today, I do have a journal which I've only started a week or two ago.  I do love lavender too, will try that as well.  It's been one heck of a Christmas being diagnosed on the 19th Dec - with every appointment a new bombshell, it is treatable.  So has taken me a while to digest and process the news especially when my 6 and 10yr old are running circles around me.
Posts.Title: Not Sleeping

Posts.Content: I did see it...very funny, I can see myself posting something at 2am :-)  Couch in March, trying not to think how different I will be feeling by then...ugh...so glad there is so much supportxx
Posts.Title: Not Sleeping

Posts.Content: Thank you for being such a Gparkle(s), this really helps.  I will try the breathing exercises, I did eventually fall asleep on the couch last night and woke up to a zombie movie!  I am going to try a herbal tea which I've bought in a health food store today, I do have a journal which I've only started a week or two ago.  I do love lavender too, will try that as well.  It's been one heck of a Christmas being diagnosed on the 19th Dec - with every appointment a new bombshell, it is treatable.  So has taken me a while to digest and process the news especially when my 6 and 10yr old are running circles around me.
Posts.Title: Not Sleeping

Posts.Content: Masectomy in two weeks, followed by Tamoxifen, chemo and radio.  Haven't hit my fifties though am not angry but just sad,  Am feeling incredibly well physically (no symptoms) so I have incredible highs and incredible lows at night.  I basically detest going to sleep, and anxious and a bit weepy (and am not one to cry).  A colleague of mine mentioned about anti-depressants (am not depressed) or meditation music or even watching Downtown Abbey back to back (which I couldn't quite believe...seriously?  And there is no way I am taking sleeping pills either.  I am sure I will have quite a cocktail of drugs soon enough....Oh yes, I even got annoyed at my husband snoring away.  Bought myself a new sofa last week.
Posts.Title: Not Sleeping

Posts.Content: Masectomy in two weeks, followed by Tamoxifen, chemo and radio.  Haven't hit my fifties though am not angry but just sad,  Am feeling incredibly well physically (no symptoms) so I have incredible highs and incredible lows at night.  I basically detest going to sleep, and anxious and a bit weepy (and am not one to cry).  A colleague of mine mentioned about anti-depressants (am not depressed) or meditation music or even watching Downtown Abbey back to back (which I couldn't quite believe...seriously?  And there is no way I am taking sleeping pills either.  I am sure I will have quite a cocktail of drugs soon enough....Oh yes, I even got annoyed at my husband snoring away.  Bought myself a new sofa last week.
Posts.Title: Not Sleeping

Posts.Content: Had herbal tea - it was lovely, but still wide awake.  It's such a long journey two operations and Chemo, I shall keep everything crossed for you that the 2nd round will not be too bad.  It's not easy with young children, but it must be difficult for you as well, mothers always want to protect and shield their children whatever the age, they do keep us soldiering on!!  I am having my second round of results on Wednesday, and my pre-op on Thursday - so not looking forward...
Posts.Title: Not Sleeping

Posts.Content: Thanks for sharing, really interesting article.  I have not heard whether fasting makes chemo more effective.  I have always been slim and have lost a bit of weight, the oncologist did say that it was actually better being thin as there was not much feeding ground lol!  Anyway, I honestly don't know who o believe - am not a smoker, drinker, and have a fairly veggie diet, breastfed and I still caught it... Also, it's not so good making the body too weak by fasting....
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and fasting

Posts.Content: That is so sweet!!  Anti bacterial spray, you can get some nice ones in the aromatherapy section where it's a little bit less clinical, anti bacterial wipes, tissues, lip moisturiser, also hand cream though not perfumed, was told aveeno cream is very good.  I was very thirsty at first with a very dry mouth.  Ah yes, anti-sickness bracelets...though I have not tried these, I went straight for the meds!  You need to drink lots at first, perhaps a tea they might like?  Big hugs xx
Posts.Title: Supporting my SIL

Posts.Content: I can really relate to the 'mess' we are all in, the Royal Marsden is excellent, they are really into their research, and I did feel that I was dealt as an 'individual' case rather than just following a standard treatment.  Here is the link, perhaps this might help you decide whether this is right or not for you?  Can your French oncologist recommend anyone?  https://www.royalmarsden.nhs.uk/our-consultants-units-and-wards/consultant-directory/dr-marina-parton https://www.royalmarsden.nhs.uk/our-consultants-units-and-wards/consultant-directory/professor-ian-smith Sending hugs from afar xxx
Posts.Title: Recommendations for an oncologist

Posts.Content: Hi Baki Not sure what MBC is...if it;s (medullary) breast cancer then I would suggest the Royal Marsden Hospital  in London.  I received a second opinion - which I had to pay for as time was working against me.  I saw Professor smith - I am not in his care, as I cannot afford private treatment, but am seeing a different oncologist at Maidstone.  He is incredibly good and humane.  My treatment plan was changed following his appointment.  It's heart breaking there are so many of us on these pages xxx
Posts.Title: Recommendations for an oncologist

Posts.Content: Hi Concepta My husband was in complete denial even after I had told him that after my mammogram, the oncologist had said the likelihood was that it was cancer.  He refused to talk about it, and said that all would go back to 'normal' after I had the mastectomy and that nothing would change.  I think what really shook him was when I came back from hospital.  It took a good 2 months, and he is so much more supportive, although I will say there are times at night, that if I ask him for an opinion about for instance PICC or no PiCC - he would say I don't know, up to you.  The usual.  As Judith said, do make him feel included, I take my husband at every single appointment whether he likes it or not.  Ha!Ha!  I found Macmillan ladies here so supportive and amazing advice.  I don't think I would have been able to approach all my fears and anxieties without there help.  So if you are feeling down, and not finding that support at home, one thing is sure you will find it here. I think he is probably very scared, and would rather hide underneath a blanket rather than facing what is to come.  Sending you hugs, hang in there xxxx
Posts.Title: Mental block .

Posts.Content: I have been experiencing for a few months constant pain on the left side of my breast - where I've had my op, so the bad side.  It's on my the lower side of the rib cage and below.  The breast itself feels fine.  It's feels like I;ve been sunburnt or scalded and at times sensitive to touch, a bit like sun burnt.  Though it's not red.  Also sore. At first I thought it may have been my bra, so have changed this to a very soft one but no real relief.   I've picked up some courage and have spoken to the breast nurse today.  She seems to think it's nerve pain but will speak to one of the surgeons next week.  She said she doesn't want to put me through the worry of having a scan.  But how would they know first hand if it's that and not the OTHER?  It's not agonising pain but something am aware of, especially at night.  Has anyone experienced or experiencing this?
Posts.Title: Is it nerve pain?

Posts.Content: What a great trhread!   I had a bit of a moment myself this morning at work at 8:30am.  My hair has been growing back the past few months, and am starting to become a bit fed up with comments on the way my hair looks.  A lady at work commented, this morning on how well my hair is growing back, how curly and thick it is.  She then started to say that her sister in law's hair was growing back too but that she was happy with how it looked and how she didn't want to dye it.  At which point I blurted out, oh well anything looks better than having a bald head.  I hope I didn't come across as being insensitive.  Eeek.
Posts.Title: "At Least"

Posts.Content: Leolady56  U think you've hit the nail on the head, I think it's because I haven't been given the all clear, and because am on a drugs trial which isn't going that well, I think is adding to my worry.  Am not worried about the pain I guess I am looking for some reassurance that's it's nothing to do with the cancer.  Glad that the breast nurse is going to ask.  Sometimes it's easy to forget that our bodies take a long time to heal.  Reading your post has made me feel so much lighter.  xxx
Posts.Title: Is it nerve pain?

Posts.Content: So funny!!!  Hilarious.  It is definitely that, I've been to hospital three times this week, and next week GP x2 hospital.  It's the in/out, and I'd rather not shake it all about.  I've gone insane as well, the other night I slept on one side rather than the other thinking oh well if I put too much pressure, then the cancer cells might just dig deeper. Nighty, nights are not good.   Am not too worried now as I have voiced my worry.  Will try to have lots of fun with family this weekend.  Big hugs, hope you have a lovely weekend - Lovely Loelady!
Posts.Title: Is it nerve pain?

Posts.Content: No way!! I don't think people really understand what you are going through, and probably by saying that you look well and that it's all nearly back to normal, they think they are being supportive.  But it all comes across as being unrealistic and insincere.  Before being struck by cancer, I don't think I could empathise myself.  I have had a mastectomy 3 weeks ago and I was telling my sister yesterday that I was surprised that I came out of surgery feeling relieved and quite unscathed by the experience, and she commented 'Well, people have implants for 'cosmetic' reasons'.  I didn't think much of it at the time, but only afterwards did it really start to sink it.  I have only been diagnosed in December, and have a long journey ahead, with my first round of chemo next Friday.  But all I can say, those who have really been there for me, are those I expected the least.  But everyone does try to help in the best way they can.  Stay true to your colours.  Let them shine - we like that!!!  Hope you like the lyrics. https://www.bing.com/search?q=true+colours,+cindy+lauper&form=IE11TR&src=IE11TR&pc=EUPP_DCJB 4:07 · HD You with the sad eyes Don't be discouraged Oh I realize Its hard to take courage In a world full of people You can lose sight of it all And the darkness inside you Can make you feel so small But I see your true colors Shining through I see your true colors And that's why I love you So don't be afraid to let them show Your true colors True colors are beautiful Like a rainbow
Posts.Title: You must be nearly better now!!! What a whimp!

Posts.Content: It wasn't as bad as I imagined, I had a mastectomy with implant back in March.  My advice is take the pain killers - paracetamol - I forgot to take mine I think on night 3 - and I woke up in a lot of pain in hospital, so they gave me a mild form of morphine - which made me trip - it was horrible.  I don't remember being in much pain, the drains can be a bit of a pain as I was house bound for 10 days, but otherwise, you can pretty much move around.  The boob feels really numb but that's normal am told.  Hope it all goes well. xxx
Posts.Title: Masectomy

Posts.Content: I love your response Swampy, I might have to just pinch that off you in a few months time...it's so spot on.  xx
Posts.Title: You must be nearly better now!!! What a whimp!

Posts.Content: Hi Kim, I have small children as well, and it's probably the scariest journey imaginable, but you will honestly get through it with good and bad days.  I have had a mastectomy and on the first course of chemo treatment.  All I can say is to take everything a little bit at a time, there is so much to digest and I found it all to overwhelming at first (and now too!).  I think you are doing the best you can do for now, the fact that you have know steps forward it gives you time to prepare yourself.  I found it good to prepare the schools, and sought help from the experienced ladies on this site.  They are incredibly supportive and knowledgeable.  They also made me laugh and giggle.  We owe it to ourselves to get through it, it's a real stinker of a disease.
Posts.Title: Stage 1 grade 3 , 7mm lump terrified :(

Posts.Content: I had good and bad days with chemo.  I suffered bad headaches (paracetamol helped), constipation, nausea and diarrhea (which was able to control with diet).  Scalp is a bit sore now and hair is falling. I decided to opt of rhte PICC line as I can only use one arm, and apparently chemo damages the veins.  I found it hard not able to plan anything, but have decided to go back to work on a flexible basis as I could not cope being at home.  Do ask lots of questions, they will go through all the symptoms but it affects everyone differently.  You will need to drink a lot after the chemo and then your first wee is red.  I felt quite ill 6 hours after the chemo and nights were the worst.  The first week is not so nice and then I started feeling a little bit better.  I have my next one next week.  Eeeek....Big hugs.
Posts.Title: Stage 1 grade 3 , 7mm lump terrified :(

Posts.Content: Hi OCR Kate, it must have a been such a tough decision to take, doctoIrs are there to guide us, but ultimately the decision is ours.  If your sanity is at stake, then that takes priority.  I just hope through it all, you will not let the cancer beat you down.  It's there to be conquered.  We are all here for you.  Do keep on posting xx
Posts.Title: A very hard decision

Posts.Content: Hi lovely Nicole279 I am further along than you are, I was diagnosed before Christmas, and I completely understand what you mean by being unsure of how you are meant to feel.  I couldn't quite believe I had cancer, I was feeling so healthy and well, and I remember coming out of the patients room, and it was someone had pulled a rug on me.  I just didn't know what to do.  I found it easier reaching to the lovely ladies here, they do really understand and are so non judgemental.  Truly amazing advice.  I also found it easier to speak to a counsellor, she really helped me move forward, and was able to approach treatment and off load as such.  I just was not able to do that with my friends and family, as much as they wanted to help, I Just felt they didn't really understand what I was going through.  Be true and gentle to yourself you have a tough week ahead with so many appointments, I hope you will not have to wait for the results too long.  xxx
Posts.Title: Someone to talk to

Posts.Content: I am so, so sorry to hear, hoping you'd make a lucky escape. The wait is awful, but it's good that they are checking everything,  Did they say what type of surgery you would be having?  i am due for my masectomy on the 9th Feb, it was meant to the week earlier.  I am now a bit more relieved all is confirmed so that I can look ahead.  Do take tiny steps, as sometimes if we deal with the larger picture at first, it becomes very difficult.  Hope you are getting lots of comfort xx
Posts.Title: Update after biopsy results today

Posts.Content: Oh gosh, it's a real blow.  I'm having the full works as well, it's good to know I've found a companion - I'm having the mastectomy first with immediate reconstruction.  I don't think I could have opted for anything other than this as I didn't fancy having surgery 1.5 years down the line.  Although I am aware of the risks of radiotherapy.  There is so much to take on so took me a while to take all of it on board.  Do keep us posted on Wednesday. Hang in therexx
Posts.Title: Update after biopsy results today

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with BC over Christmas, had mastectomy!  and just finished chemo so now 6 months down the line...I am just so fed up of being asked so HOW ARE YOU?  Honestly, am sh&*((   Why don't you ask me out for a drink instead?!  I could actually do with one.  It just leads to nothing, and just feeds into their curiosity.  So, so sorry for the rant but I have been buggered all week with this.  I've said it, feel better now xxx
Posts.Title: How are you?

Posts.Content: I had an immediate reconstruction with implant although I was Tod that radiotherapy may damage the implant within a year I just don't think I could have coped with the emotional and physical scaring after the op and chemo. The healing time is not painful and was only given paracetamol and iboprufej. Washing was a bit of a pain with the drains but I soon got used to it. Go with what you think is right for you. There is not much fat on me so I didn't think the other options were right for me. You will find that everyone carries a different suit case on this journey. Big hugs xx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy Choices....Any Thoughts?

Posts.Content: Dear SazzatI A heartfelt hug to your sister, you and your family.  It's a huge blow and it will take time for your sister to come to terms with it.  I am in a similar situation as your sister, mine started off as one lump, then it became 2 and then all my lymph nodes on the left side had cancer.  This means that although CT scans were clear, there is a high percentage that my cancer has spread elsewhere.  However, I was told by a reputable oncologist that many people with similar diagnosis live on for many, many years.  I was asked if I needed anti-depressants, definitely not!  It's so important to be able to laugh, cry, rant, and share.  I am seeing a councellor through a charity group, my first session was today.  It was hard, but it helped talking to someone who was not  family.  Perhaps, this might help your sister as she is going through chemo.  I have 2 children - 6 and 11yrs.  Do keep on sharing, big, big hugs xxxx
Posts.Title: New here and supporting my sister with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thank you for sharing it is very hopeful, though I did cry a little.
Posts.Title: BBC Scotland Beaston Cancer Centre - Episode One Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Julie From a personal point of view, I think they can tell by looking at the mammogram and ultrasound.  I was 'diagnosed' a bit like you (though I don't know what grade I was) just before Christmas, though all that was said was that I need more tests - i.e bone and MRI scan.  That completely through me off (as I honestly didn't think anything of it, I though they would say I had a small cyst) I asked what the likelihood was - good or bad.  They said bad.  C word was not mentioned.  If it is, breast cancer is very treatable these days.  Please do not worry or over think it, the worst thing is the wait, but I was amazed by the level of NHS care, they do look at everything so nothing gets missed.  You are in very good hands.  Sending you lots of hugs!! xx
Posts.Title: Recall for Mammogram

Posts.Content: Hi Julie, am truly sorry to hear, I still struggle to understand terminology, what is WLE and SNB?  It's good that you dodged the chemo bullet and that you can start treatment in two weeks, which is pretty quick.  Sending you lots of hugs. xxx
Posts.Title: Recall for Mammogram

Posts.Content: Hi Lucy B, I can't believe how rude, and insensitive your oncologist was for taking 3 calls, it's not as if you were diagnosed with a broken foot.  I had a similar experience with my first oncologist, who walked out of the room after a few minutes and left me with her oncologist consultant who was also incredibly rude - said I was a control freak for asking questions, and then asked if I wanted anti depressants because I broke down - it was just too much to take in.  All I wanted to say that if you are in doubt, don't stick with it.  I asked for a second opinion - I didn't have any confidence, and then proceeded with asking to have a different consultant.  It was a very hard thing to do, but am so glad I did, as it happens the oncologist I have listens to me, and has changed type of chemo and hormone treatment.  Do make sure you are in control of your body.  Macmillan ladies were of huge support, although we all have very different treatment plans, they have been a great source of courage and strength.
Posts.Title: Through first week of 1st Cyle of fec-t

Posts.Content: Hi Lucy B, I can't believe how rude, and insensitive your oncologist was for taking 3 calls, it's not as if you were diagnosed with a broken foot.  I had a similar experience with my first oncologist, who walked out of the room after a few minutes and left me with her oncologist consultant who was also incredibly rude - said I was a control freak for asking questions, and then asked if I wanted anti depressants because I broke down - it was just too much to take in.  All I wanted to say that if you are in doubt, don't stick with it.  I asked for a second opinion - I didn't have any confidence, and then proceeded with asking to have a different consultant.  It was a very hard thing to do, but am so glad I did, as it happens the oncologist I have listens to me, and has changed type of chemo and hormone treatment.  Do make sure you are in control of your body.  Macmillan ladies were of huge support, although we all have very different treatment plans, they have been a great source of courage and strength.
Posts.Title: Through first week of 1st Cyle of fec-t

Posts.Content: How about this one...though we are the ones to roar like champions!! www.bing.com/search
Posts.Title: Something I’d like to share

Posts.Content: I was just reading the news headlines and was incredibly saddened to read that Rachael Bland (I am not familiar with the name), a news presenter, in her 40's with a 2year old child was recently diagnosed with incurable cancer.  She received a call while she was out with her child that it was 'bad news'.  How can someone to be told over the phone such terrible news?!   I find it difficult to comprehend that there is no reason or rhyme to this disease.  My heart goes out to each and every single person battling any shape or form of cancer.  Feeling incredibly sad.
Posts.Title: So sad

Posts.Content: Hi Gail & Optimistic, it's just so sad that every single day, there is someone out there who has just been diagnosed, it's awful when it strikes someone with a young family, but it's also sad at any age.  There are lots of positive stories, but it's the individual struggles that bear a real significance to me.  It's the real people behind these, and because I am going through it, it just makes it all the more painful to watch as a bystander, and not be able to help.  I guess it's that helpless feeling.   All these Macmillan ladies are amazing.  Sending lots, and lots of hugs  xx
Posts.Title: So sad

Posts.Content: Hi Puplepants, I love your name!!  It would be a bit strange if you didn't feel anxious, apiprehensive, worried.  I read that you have a fairly young family - I have two children aged 7 & 11 (going on 16! - though very sweet).and your a working mum too.  You must feel likeI you are carrying the world over your shoulder.  Once number one is done - I would recommend a PICC line, it will be easier.   Just take it one step at a time, the way I tried to see it that if I felt rough then it was a good thing, it was having some effect.  I also carried on working but had the first few days off after chemo.  The journey is so individual.  Sending virtual hugs xxxx
Posts.Title: So anxious....

Posts.Content: Gosh, I've had those thoughts/feelings, and felt really guilty having them.  Am right of the bottom of the mountain, and I really don't fancy the hike.  Thanks for sharing xx
Posts.Title: Something I’d like to share

Posts.Content: x3 Fec over, had my first round of Paclitaxel - not nice.  They gave me something along the lines of Priton, it brought on a terrible migrane which I tried to sleep off while I was there!  Remember thinking this is just too much.  And then horrible tummy upset at home.  Slept for a few hours on couch now wide awake...somehow don't think I will make it in to work.  Hate giving in to this illness, but I guess it's for a good cause.  Now feeling much brighter. Thank you all for posting.  Lovely to hear people are 'awake'. xx
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Wink, I think so...I wake up in the middle of the night hot and flustered.  Then I seem to cool off.  Sometimes during the day,  but often at night.  On Friday  night I woke up at 3am and was wide awake, did not get back to sleep.  Whereas last night, I was only awake for a short while I think, luckily managed to get back to sleep. It's injection night for me tonight...What chemo are you on?  xx
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: I have just had x3 FEC and due to have my first round of Paclitaxel tomorrow.  Every 2 weeks - 4 rounds.  I had fairly mild symptoms with FEC but am quite worried about Paclitaxel.  As recovery time is short is it going to hit me quite hard...sometimes I wonder if the not knowing would have been better than the knowing.  I know it sounds crazy, just dreading the journey and the 'new normal'.  FEC was about 1.5 hrs whereas Paclitaxel is 4 hours.  That seems like quite a lot of drugs being pumped.  Sorry, if it seems silly, I just need a download. xxx
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Thank you, due to have a mastectomy in 2 weeks as cancer has spread to lymphnode, I did not realise that it becomes uncurable once it spreads to other parts of the body.  Gosh am so scared, I would rather have the side effects of biophosphates than running this risk.  Not sure if this will be part of my treatment plan but will ask.  I feel with cancer you close one door and open another.  If I could fast forward the clock I would.  Roll on 2019!!!
Posts.Title: NICE draft guidelines on treatment of primary breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Jac, I know your post was not meant to scare, it's just the breadth of all the scenarios and different treatments.  what really haunts me is that the first thing my surgeon when diagnosing me was 'one thing I want you to remember is your cancer is 'treatable'. Yet I still question the fact why did didn't say 'curable'.  Having to go through it all and yet there is no 'guarantee' So although I do keep informed, I find any literature quite unsettling.   How amazing you are nearing the end of treatment - I have yet to begin...hoping the oncologist will go easy on me...xxx
Posts.Title: NICE draft guidelines on treatment of primary breast cancer

Posts.Content: I am a newby, joined a few weeks ago and coming to terms with BC diagnoses stage 2, spread to lymphnode, so due to have a m'astectomy in 3 weeks time, then Tamoxifen, chemo and radio.  I have two young children aged 6 and 10, and my parents (aged 80, dadd with Parkinson's)  both living in Italy as well as my sisters.  I have told my eldest sister but not my other sister and my parents.  As are going through a hard time, at the moment I really don't want to say anything as I think this would really upset them, and they are the type of parents that if I do not return a call within the hour they panic to the point where they think I've had some sort of accident.  I've explained this to my sister, and she basically said that as a family we all need to stick together, and if I don't tell them I would be basically rejecting family, and they would all support me.  Whereas, I don't think I could cope with someone else magnifying the issue.  Also, I did have a little bit of a wobble over the phone, as at every single appointment I've had the picture seems to get larger and larger with early menopause, lymphodeama, possibly more operations with cancer and having to live with physical and emotional changes after cancer. I know she was probably being supportive, but being told it will be will be all over by the end of the year, and it the outlook is 'positive' and that  will be cancer free I need to rejoice in that.  It was almost as if someone was making light of it.  Asking 'why ae you worried about the menoupause...I've gone through it'.  Sorry don't mean to have a rant, it just makes me feel better.  I just felt horrible and shaky after the call..Any suggestions on how best to deal with family?
Posts.Title: Telling Family

Posts.Content: Thank you ladies for the incredibly valuable support, I've read your post a few 'times' over today and I felt much stronger as to what I should be doing/saying next.  My eldest sister knows the finer details whereas I have only told my middle sister today that what I have is a very small (I wish!) malignant tumor and that I am waiting to receive confirmation as to when minor surgery (vs mastectomy) is due.  Gives me a little bit more time to tell my parents a similar version of events.   I told a little lie, saying I had yet to tell my eldest sister, so then strangely enough she called me afterwards to check with me how my other sister had taken and reacted to the news.  Then she went on to say what a tough week she had as her kids had been off school with flu over the past week.  So that did really put my mind to rest, that yes, it's so true one must have a List A - List B - List C.  I will mention treatment ahead whenever I think I am ready to share.  It's so difficult to decide what is right or wrong with this disease, there is no right or wrong, and it affects everyone in different ways.  It's nice to know that I am not alone.  Thank you so much I couldn't have made that call on my own if it wasn't for everyone's input and advice.   .
Posts.Title: Telling Family
